item.title: [GROOVY-5632] Closure default params can cause BUG! exception in phase 'class generation'
item.description:
Default parameters for methods can be used in further default parameters, ie:

def f( int x, fn={ -> x } ) {
  fn()
}

f( 10 )

(outputs 10)

However, if I give x a default value:

def f( int x=3, fn={ -> x } ) {
  fn()
}

f( 10 )

comments.comment:
I just stumbled across the same issue. I guess the problem is caused by the generated non-parameter method f() which in fact creates (invalid) code similar to

def f() {
    this.f((Object) 3, (Object) { -> x })
}
I guess the Verifier generating the default value methods should handle this situation. I see if I can provide a fix.
Here is the pull request: https://github.com/groovy/groovy-core/pull/80

A possible alternative path to the pull request could be that for "f( int x=3, fn=

{ -> x }

)" we create f()

{ f(3) }

, f(int x) { f(x,{-> x}}, f(x,fn)

{fn()}

. Right now there are direct calls to the two argument function. With many default parameters though this could lead more easily to a StackOverflowException.
